You can't prove anything in the present by citing evidence that will supposedly be discovered in the future.
 
 Claims about the afterlife invariably rest upon what you will find out after you die. Dying is the only way to observe the world of the afterlife, and that's a one-way road.
 
 "What you will find out when you die" is future evidence. The key word is "will" which is the English future-tense word.
 
 Therefore, no claim about the afterlife can be proven in this life. 
 
 So threats of Hell are empty.
 
 It's just common sense.

 The Pauline passage in question does not say what the Study Note claims it does. Paul refers to a requirement to 'do by nature things required by the law' and to 'show that the requirements of the law are written on their hearts'.
 
 Staying, for the moment, with the Mayans. They sacrificed to gods such as Tlaloc and Chalchiuhtlicue, of whom they also made graven images. They assuredly did not, therefore, 'do by nature things required by the law' or 'show that the requirements of the law are written on their hearts'. So, they're all in hell, right? 
 
 Or does the Paul quote really mean that anything goes for a people, as long as the word hasn't reached them? That Aztec priests who tore the hearts out of human captives and offered them to Quetzalcoatl, are now in heaven, 'cos they knew no better at the time? If so, the advice for any remaining unreached people should be to keep the missionaries at bay at all costs: just as long as you haven't heard the word, you can do what you like and still be saved.
 
 By contrast, the Study Note simply says 'Their judgment will be on other grounds', with no mention of the law. This still seems at best arbitrary, since the people in question can have no way of knowing what those grounds might be. If it's a matter, as you suggest, of having a clear conscience, the Aztec priest I referred to is home and dry, since he will have known that tearing live kids' hearts out was righteous.
 
 Finally, I note that you still evade the issue of whether a deity sending a clone of itself to earth so that it can sacrifice itself to itself and thereby enable itself to give everyone a fresh start actually makes any sense at all, regardless of how incompetently it may have been done. I reiterate that it does not.
